title: Approaches for delivery of refractive and optical care services in community and primary care settings
authors: Umaefulam, V; Safi, S; Lingham, G; Gordon, I; Mueller, A; Krishnam, NS.; Alves Carneiro, V; Yu, M; Evans, JR; Keel, S

response.output:
What are the best ways to provide eye care services in community and primary care settings to correct vision problems (such as refractive errors)?
- We are not sure about the benefits and harms of different ways to provide local eye care. This is because there was not enough good-quality evidence.
- We found several ways that eye care is provided, such as in schools, pharmacies, mobile clinics, and health centres.
- Future research should test how well these different ways of providing eye care work. This will help fill the gaps in our knowledge and guide countries on how to improve their eye care services.

What is uncorrected refractive error and why is it a problem?
Uncorrected refractive error is a leading cause of vision impairment worldwide. It occurs when the shape of the eye bends light incorrectly, which makes things look blurry. This condition can usually be fixed with the right pair of glasses, but many people, especially in low-resource settings, do not have access to eye care services.

What did the review authors want to find out?
The review authors aimed to determine the range of approaches for delivering eye care services in community and primary care settings. They also wanted to identify the methods used to evaluate these approaches, in order to help create guidelines for countries on how to improve their eye care services.

What methods did the review authors use?
We searched for studies that described different ways of providing eye care in local communities. We wanted to see what models were used and find out if researchers had tested how well they worked.

What were the main results of the review?
We found several ways that eye care is delivered. In the community, this included services in schools, pharmacies, and mobile outreach clinics. In primary care settings, services were offered in vision centres, health centres, or through door-to-door visits.

What are the limitations of the evidence?
We have little confidence in the evidence because the studies were small. Also, very few studies had actually tested how well these different ways of providing eye care worked, so we don't know which are best.

Is the evidence up to date?
The evidence is up to date to November 2022.
